practitioner_domains.domain_description: Clinical cancer treatment and management focusing on all solid tumors with subspecialty interest in breast cancer
practitioner_domains.specialization_notes: Half of clinical time spent in actual cancer treatment, focus on solid tumors

practitioner_domains.domain_description: Systematic approach to catching cancer early across all solid tumor types through blood work, imaging, physical assessments and surveys
practitioner_domains.specialization_notes: Clinic focused on opportunities to catch cancer early before symptoms develop

practitioner_domains.domain_description: Comprehensive evaluation of cancer risk factors including genetics, family history, and lifestyle factors to stratify risk and guide screening protocols
practitioner_domains.specialization_notes: Chairs high-risk breast cancer program, expertise in genetic cancer risk assessment

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Lifetime and 10-year probability of developing breast cancer based on personal history, family history, genetics, and lifestyle factors
constructs_mentioned.assessment_context: Primary construct evaluated through multiple risk calculators and genetic testing

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Categorization of breast tissue density (A, B, C, D) that affects both cancer detection ability and inherent cancer risk
constructs_mentioned.assessment_context: Automated assessment from mammography imaging, influences supplemental screening recommendations

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Inherited genetic mutations that significantly increase cancer risk across multiple cancer types
constructs_mentioned.assessment_context: Assessed through family pedigree analysis and genetic testing for hereditary cancer syndromes

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Assessment of whether mammographic images adequately capture all breast tissue with sufficient positioning and compression
constructs_mentioned.assessment_context: Third-party software evaluation of image acquisition quality and tissue positioning

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Distribution of lean muscle mass, body fat percentage, and visceral adipose tissue that influences cancer risk calculations
constructs_mentioned.assessment_context: Component of lifestyle factors affecting BMI-based risk calculations in Tyrer-Cuzick model

assessments.assessment_description: A questionnaire-based tool that evaluates personal and family history to determine lifetime and 10-year breast cancer risk using validated calculators like Tyrer-Cusk and Gail models

Advanced X-ray imaging technology that captures multiple images to create three-dimensional views of breast tissue, often enhanced with AI-assisted computer-aided detection (CAD) for pattern recognition
Supplemental imaging assessment used in conjunction with mammography, particularly for women with dense breast tissue to identify lesions that may not be visible on mammogram alone
High-resolution magnetic resonance imaging of both breasts, typically recommended for high-risk patients (>20% lifetime risk) as interval screening every 6 months
DNA analysis via blood or saliva sample to identify hereditary cancer mutations such as BRCA1/BRCA2, performed by specialized laboratories when patients meet NCCN criteria
Third-party software evaluation to determine if mammographic images were acquired with adequate positioning and tissue capture, ensuring comprehensive breast tissue visualization

interventions.intervention_description: Additional imaging modalities including whole breast ultrasound and bilateral breast MRI recommended based on breast density categories and risk assessment scores to improve cancer detection in high-risk patients
Hyper-tailored imaging cadence based on individual risk factors, including more frequent screening intervals (every 6 months) for high-risk patients instead of standard annual screening
5-year anti-estrogen medication therapy for women with greater than 1.66% annual breast cancer risk based on Gail calculator, shown to reduce breast cancer incidence by 50%
DNA testing through blood or saliva samples to identify hereditary cancer mutations, followed by genetic counseling to understand implications and develop management strategies

interventions.intervention_name: Family Risk Assessment and Cascade Testing
interventions.intervention_description: Contacting and screening DNA relatives of patients with identified genetic mutations or cancer diagnoses to prevent cancer in family members through early detection
Targeted interventions to improve BMI, reduce visceral fat, and optimize lean muscle mass to lower breast cancer risk through improved body composition metrics
Comprehensive lifestyle modification program addressing the six pillars: exercise, nutrition, sleep, stress management, social connection, and avoiding risky behaviors to reduce cancer risk

Educational intervention to reduce alcohol consumption as part of avoiding risky behaviors, addressing both direct cancer risk and indirect effects through improved metabolic health and body composition
Implementation of third-party image quality assessment using software like Densitas to ensure optimal breast tissue capture and positioning for accurate cancer detection

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Higher breast density makes it harder to see through tissue, reducing mammogram effectiveness
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Dense breasts are tightly packed and harder to see through, making mammogram alone incomplete

construct_relationships.relationship_description: BMI changes affect breast cancer risk calculations, with higher BMI increasing risk
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: BMI is used in Tyrer-Cuzick calculations and affects risk scores

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Inherited mutations dramatically increase breast cancer risk from 12.5% to 60-80% lifetime risk
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: BRCA2 mutations increase risk dramatically, though only 5% of breast cancers are BRCA positive

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Breast density is a risk factor incorporated into lifetime risk calculations
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Density categories A,B,C,D have different implications for risk and screening recommendations

interpretation_factors: Patient knowledge of family medical history

intervention_construct_links.mechanism_of_action: Provides additional imaging modalities to overcome limitations of mammography alone
intervention_construct_links.timeline_expectations: Immediate diagnostic benefit at time of imaging

intervention_construct_links.mechanism_of_action: Tailors imaging frequency and modalities based on individual risk assessment
intervention_construct_links.timeline_expectations: Ongoing benefit with regular screening intervals

intervention_construct_links.mechanism_of_action: Anti-estrogen medication reduces cancer development by blocking estrogen receptors
intervention_construct_links.timeline_expectations: 5-year treatment course for risk reduction

intervention_construct_links.mechanism_of_action: Identifies hereditary mutations and provides risk counseling
intervention_construct_links.timeline_expectations: Immediate results with lifelong implications

intervention_construct_links.intervention_name: Family Risk Assessment and Cascade Testing
intervention_construct_links.mechanism_of_action: Extends genetic risk assessment to family members based on proband results
expected_outcomes: Early detection in high-risk family members
intervention_construct_links.timeline_expectations: Ongoing family screening and prevention

intervention_construct_links.mechanism_of_action: Improves lean muscle mass and reduces body fat percentage to lower cancer risk
intervention_construct_links.timeline_expectations: Gradual improvement over months to years

intervention_construct_links.mechanism_of_action: Addresses exercise, nutrition, sleep, stress, social connection, and risky behaviors
intervention_construct_links.timeline_expectations: Continuous benefit with sustained lifestyle changes

intervention_construct_links.mechanism_of_action: Reduces liquid sugar intake and metabolic cancer drivers
intervention_construct_links.timeline_expectations: Gradual improvement with sustained behavior change

intervention_construct_links.mechanism_of_action: Ensures proper breast positioning and complete tissue capture during imaging
intervention_construct_links.timeline_expectations: Immediate improvement in image quality

assessment_intervention_connections.connection_description: Survey results determine if patient qualifies for genetic testing based on NCCN criteria
Mammogram density results (C or D) trigger recommendation for whole breast ultrasound
Tyrer-Cuzick scores >20% trigger MRI recommendations, 15-20% trigger ultrasound

assessment_intervention_connections.intervention_name: Family Risk Assessment and Cascade Testing
assessment_intervention_connections.connection_description: Positive genetic results initiate family member risk assessment and testing
BMI component of risk assessment identifies need for body composition intervention
Quality assessment results inform need for positioning and technique improvements
Risk assessment results motivate comprehensive lifestyle interventions for risk reduction

metrics.interpretation_notes: Greater than 20% qualifies for high-risk category and MRI screening
Less actionable than lifetime risk
Used to determine eligibility for tamoxifen chemoprevention
Category C or D requires supplemental ultrasound imaging
AI marks suspicious areas with concern ratings

metrics.normal_ranges: Qualifies or does not qualify based on NCCN guidelines
metrics.interpretation_notes: Rules-based engine determines genetic testing eligibility
Only 5% of breast cancers are BRCA positive but dramatically changes risk profile
Used in Tyrer-Cuzick calculation, modifiable risk factor

client_goals.goal_description: Early detection of breast cancer to catch cancer in early stages
client_goals.timeline: Ongoing screening with annual mammograms, 6-month MRI intervals for high-risk
client_goals.priority_level: High - early detection equals less treatment, improved quality of life, less cost

client_goals.goal_description: Identify and modify breast cancer risk factors
client_goals.timeline: Continuous - risk is dynamic and changes over time
client_goals.priority_level: High - create agency and empower individuals

client_goals.goal_description: Precision screening tailored to individual risk profile
client_goals.timeline: Varies by risk: annual for average risk, 6-month intervals for high risk
client_goals.priority_level: High - simple mammogram alone is not enough for high-risk women

constraints_preferences.description: Less than half of breast imaging centers perform proper risk assessment
constraints_preferences.impact_on_assessment: Many women don't receive comprehensive breast cancer risk evaluation
constraints_preferences.impact_on_intervention: Limits ability to stratify screening and prevention strategies
workaround_strategies: Implement high-risk programs at imaging centers

constraints_preferences.description: Comprehensive risk surveys are too complicated to administer at point of care
constraints_preferences.impact_on_assessment: Surveys sent ahead of time, only 50% completion rate
constraints_preferences.impact_on_intervention: Incomplete risk stratification leads to suboptimal screening recommendations

constraints_preferences.description: Tyrus model excludes males and patients with prior breast cancer
constraints_preferences.impact_on_assessment: Cannot assess lifetime risk in these populations
constraints_preferences.impact_on_intervention: Must rely on genetic testing and alternative risk models

constraints_preferences.description: Worldwide majority of centers still use 2D mammograms instead of 3D
constraints_preferences.impact_on_assessment: Lower resolution, higher miss rates
constraints_preferences.impact_on_intervention: May require supplemental imaging more frequently

moderating_factors.description: Patients don't understand breast density categories, biopsy results, or family history details required for surveys
moderating_factors.what_it_affects: Assessment accuracy - patients skip questions or answer inaccurately
moderating_factors.management_approach: Clinical team verification and education at visit, simplified survey language

moderating_factors.description: Need previous mammograms for comparison - looking for change over time
moderating_factors.what_it_affects: Assessment interpretation - single image set like reading one chapter of a book
moderating_factors.management_approach: Ensure centers obtain prior imaging, patient education on continuity of care

moderating_factors.description: Breast is deformable structure, image quality varies by technician skill and breast characteristics
moderating_factors.what_it_affects: Assessment reliability - may miss tissue or provide poor quality images
moderating_factors.management_approach: Third-party quality assessment tools like Densitas, technician training

moderating_factors.description: Risk changes continuously with age, hormonal status, body composition, lifestyle factors
moderating_factors.what_it_affects: Assessment validity over time - risk not static
moderating_factors.management_approach: Regular reassessment, lifestyle modification programs, continuous monitoring

individual_differences.assessment_implications: Category C/D requires supplemental ultrasound due to tissue density masking lesions
individual_differences.intervention_implications: Dense breasts need additional imaging modalities beyond mammography alone

individual_differences.assessment_implications: Postmenopausal women typically have less dense breasts, easier to image
individual_differences.intervention_implications: May require less frequent supplemental imaging as density decreases with age

individual_differences.assessment_implications: Positive family history or genetic mutations dramatically alter risk calculations
individual_differences.intervention_implications: High-risk individuals need MRI screening, genetic counseling, consideration of risk-reducing medications

individual_differences.assessment_implications: Higher BMI increases breast cancer risk in Tyrus calculations
individual_differences.intervention_implications: Weight management and body composition optimization become key intervention targets

individual_differences.assessment_implications: Lifetime risk assessment flawed for older patients - different time horizons matter
individual_differences.intervention_implications: Need age-appropriate screening intervals and risk-appropriate interventions

individual_differences.assessment_implications: Males excluded from Tyrus model but still have breast cancer risk (1% of cases)
individual_differences.intervention_implications: Must rely on genetic testing and family history for male risk assessment

potential_missed_entities.evidence_in_transcript: Quality of mammogram is something we as an organization haven't talked too much about. But there is a software company called Densitas which actually will look at the image... So there are these algorithms that have spun up that I think it would be a great service for us to think about for women just to say like was it a good quality mammogram

out of every hundred individuals that get diagnosed with breast cancer, one is a male... that doesn't mean males are not not at risk. So we should do genetic testing and family history assessments in males as well
we do a review of systems which is done by a questionnaire. Typically, it's a 14-point review of systems head to toe which identifies any symptoms that individuals may have
we generate a pedigree we look at the incidence of cancer by age and cancer type in all of their family members
there is a software company called Densitas which actually will look at the image and you can send it to a third party to see if the image was acquired with quality or not
That image then goes in lives within a pax system which is the basically the imaging warehouse and viewer for the radiologist

we may not be able to prevent cancer, breast cancer in mom who was just diagnosed, but we may be able to prevent it in her DNA relatives, including her daughters, right, and sisters and and aunts and uncles
precision screening is defined as an imaging cadence that's hyper tailored to you

alcohol and tobacco are pretty known risk factors... would an intervention for that be an educational program, intervention to, educate the individual that alcohols consumption would be would be a problem and to reduce that
there are these algorithms that have spun up... to say like was it a good quality mammogram... It's called a mammogram quality or positioning
The CAD marks literally put circles on the mammogram and say, 'Hey, look at this.' And then it gives a rating of how worried it is
Gail largely gives a five and 10year risk of breast cancer... if you have a risk of breast cancer which is greater than 1.66% per year

recommendations.description: Add mammogram quality/positioning as a distinct construct with Densitas as supporting technology and image quality score as metric
Include 14-point review of systems and pedigree analysis as formal assessment types in the breast cancer risk domain
Add PACS system as core imaging infrastructure technology that supports multiple assessment workflows
Include family member risk communication and precision screening as distinct intervention categories beyond individual patient care
Separate Gail 10-year risk score from Tyrer-Cuzick lifetime risk as distinct metrics with different clinical applications
Consider whether male breast cancer risk should be included in current domain or treated as separate construct given different risk factors and assessment approaches
Better capture the conditional logic relationships between assessment results and intervention recommendations (e.g., density category → ultrasound recommendation)

assessments.assessment_name: Hip Joint Range of Motion Assessment
assessments.assessment_description: Comprehensive evaluation of hip joint mobility including flexion, extension, internal rotation, external rotation in different positions, and combined movements like flexion-adduction-internal rotation (FADIR) and flexion-abduction-external rotation (FABER)

Isometric strength testing using force frame equipment to assess hip muscle strength in various positions including open chain internal rotation at 90 degrees, long leg straight position, long leg squeeze test, and crook bridge squeeze test
Battery of jump tests including squat jump, countermovement jump, and single leg jump performed on force plates to assess power output, balance, coordination, and bilateral asymmetries
Single leg hopping assessment to evaluate dynamic stability, power endurance, and movement control under fatigue conditions
Observational analysis of deceleration, re-acceleration, change of direction, and sport-specific movement patterns to identify compensatory strategies and movement quality
Clinical examination to identify pain-producing movements and positions, including assessment of pain sensitivity and functional limitations during movement

interventions.intervention_description: 12-week high quality conservative rehabilitation program focusing on movement strategies, strength training, and functional capacity building to avoid surgical intervention
Functional movement training and capacity building program to prepare athletes for hip surgery, focusing on movement control, load absorption, and power production across different movement patterns
Systematic progression from squat to split squat to single leg movements, advancing from concentric to eccentric loading patterns to build functional capacity
Training program targeting specific movement demands of the athlete's sport, such as reverse VH position for hockey goalies or change of direction patterns for field sports
Focused training on stopping, braking, and re-acceleration patterns to improve movement control and reduce injury risk in stop-start sports
Structured warmup routine focusing on hip activation and movement preparation to improve tissue load management and movement quality
Targeted strengthening program for hip musculature including internal/external rotation, abduction/adduction exercises using various positions and equipment
Training program incorporating single leg activities, jumping, landing, and balance challenges to improve proprioception and movement coordination
Progressive exposure to sport-specific movements and chaos-based activities to build confidence and movement variability under different conditions
Simplified supplementation program limiting to 2-3 key supplements to improve adherence, with progression only after consistent use is established

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Limited hip range of motion often correlates with pain production, particularly in flexion-adduction-internal rotation positions
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Athletes don't like flexion adduction and internal rotation positions, and these movements can produce clicking or catching

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Available hip range directly determines what movement strategies are possible, particularly in sport-specific positions
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Hockey goalies need massive internal rotation for reverse VH position - if you don't have that range, you'll get it somewhere else or peel at the labrum

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Poor movement strategies lead to increased tissue load and reduced load tolerance over time
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Poor movement strategies go hand in hand with tissue load - if you don't absorb force properly, you get more stress at other joints

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Pain inhibition causes changes in muscle activation and can lead to weakness and fatty infiltration
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Pain inhibition makes changes to muscles around the joint, sometimes causing fatty infiltration and changes in control

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Good balance control is essential for executing proper movement strategies, especially in deceleration and re-acceleration
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Need balance and coordination for single leg jumping and change of direction movements

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Force production capabilities directly relate to functional mobility and sport performance
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Even if you beautifully push a bobsled with excellent position, you won't push it fast if you don't have enough strength and power

constraints_preferences.description: Clinical vs lab-based testing environments with different equipment availability
constraints_preferences.impact_on_assessment: Less standardized conditions, potential for user error, opportunistic testing timing
constraints_preferences.impact_on_intervention: Need to adapt programs based on available resources
workaround_strategies: Use what's available but recognize limitations
Video record assessments for quality control

constraints_preferences.description: Remote/distance-based support with limited face-to-face contact
constraints_preferences.impact_on_assessment: Reduced ability to perform hands-on assessments, reliance on self-reporting
constraints_preferences.impact_on_intervention: Need for clear communication and athlete autonomy
workaround_strategies: Use technology like Plana for real-world monitoring

constraints_preferences.description: Professional athletes have limited off-season windows for intervention
constraints_preferences.impact_on_assessment: Pressure to make quick decisions about surgical vs conservative management
constraints_preferences.impact_on_intervention: Compressed timelines for achieving results

constraints_preferences.description: Complex diagnostic findings with high instance of abnormal findings in non-symptomatic patients
constraints_preferences.impact_on_assessment: Difficulty determining if imaging findings are clinically relevant
constraints_preferences.impact_on_intervention: Need to focus on functional outcomes rather than just imaging
workaround_strategies: Emphasize clinical triad of assessment, diagnostics, and function
Focus on pain-producing vs non-pain producing movements

moderating_factors.factor_name: Athlete's current state and fatigue level
moderating_factors.description: Testing conditions vary based on sleep, nutrition, training load, stress levels
moderating_factors.what_it_affects: Assessment results and interpretation of metrics
moderating_factors.management_approach: Document context of testing conditions, use pre-survey to capture current state, recognize testing is opportunistic rather than standardized

moderating_factors.description: Athletes with limited training background may lack coordination for complex assessments
moderating_factors.what_it_affects: Assessment validity and intervention design
moderating_factors.management_approach: Adjust assessment complexity based on experience level, use coordination tasks as interventions, build foundational skills first

moderating_factors.description: Different sports require different movement patterns and ranges of motion
moderating_factors.what_it_affects: Assessment selection and intervention specificity
moderating_factors.management_approach: Understand technical coach's objectives, align interventions with sport demands, consider position-specific requirements

moderating_factors.description: Existing team relationships and openness to external input varies
moderating_factors.what_it_affects: Intervention implementation and long-term success
moderating_factors.management_approach: Build relationships with existing team, use common language and metrics, empower rather than replace existing support

moderating_factors.description: Fear, confidence levels, trust in injured limb, mental connection to injury
moderating_factors.what_it_affects: Assessment performance and intervention adherence
moderating_factors.management_approach: Address confidence and fear issues, focus on building trust in movement patterns, change narrative from injury management to performance enhancement

individual_differences.assessment_implications: Younger athletes may have less consistent training schedules and testing experience
individual_differences.intervention_implications: Need more structure and education, different adherence patterns

individual_differences.assessment_implications: Different access to resources, testing environments, and time availability
individual_differences.intervention_implications: Professional athletes have more pressure for quick decisions, developmental athletes need more foundational work

individual_differences.assessment_implications: Some athletes are structure-based vs chaos-based, affecting how they respond to testing
individual_differences.intervention_implications: Need to match coaching style to athlete personality, some need data while others need simplified approaches

individual_differences.assessment_implications: Previous injuries affect movement patterns and willingness to load tissues
individual_differences.intervention_implications: Need to address compensation patterns and build confidence in previously injured areas

individual_differences.assessment_implications: Different sports have different approaches to testing and data collection
individual_differences.intervention_implications: Need to adapt communication style and intervention approach to fit sport culture

Does it produce pain or not? That's easy. Everybody can probably agree like, this is painful, this is not
was it painful? B, did it look limited?... was it relatively good? You know, like basically a three scale thing
if we've sent a supplement program, was it successful in their adherence to it?... there seems to be a magic number. If we send three or less, those get adapted

recommendations.description: Add behavioral and psychological constructs like trust-building, athlete buy-in, and adherence patterns which are heavily emphasized throughout the interview
Include context-dependent assessment protocols that account for testing environment, athlete state, and sport-specific demands rather than just standardized metrics
Better capture the interconnected nature of constructs, assessments, and interventions as described by the expert - everything is linked rather than isolated
Incorporate decision-making frameworks for when to stop assessments, escalate to practitioners, or modify interventions based on athlete capability and response
Expand sport-specific assessment and intervention categories, particularly for unique demands like hockey goaltender positioning or field hockey handedness constraints
Include comprehensive outcome measurement tools and adherence tracking mechanisms as core components of the intervention process
Account for different practitioner approaches and testing environments in the ontology structure to maintain data quality and interpretation accuracy

assessments.assessment_description: Force plate-based jumping assessment using work energy method to evaluate takeoff velocity, peak external mechanical power, breaking and propulsive power phases, and inter-limb asymmetries across bilateral and unilateral conditions
Plyometric assessment involving repeated hopping tasks (double leg or single leg) to evaluate reactive strength and elastic function over multiple ground contacts
Countermovement jump performed with 30-60% body mass loading to assess strength-power relationship and movement strategy adaptation under load
Comprehensive evaluation of fundamental movement patterns including squatting, hinging, pushing, pulling, and rotation to assess movement competency and identify compensations
Head-to-toe evaluation of range of motion and control of that range across joints to identify restrictions and movement limitations
Multi-site skinfold measurement protocol to evaluate body composition, fat distribution patterns, and overall adiposity status
Anaerobic capacity assessment involving one jump every four seconds for 82 seconds to evaluate total anaerobic capacity and fatigue index
Progressive cycling protocol to determine maximal aerobic power, training zones, and cardiovascular fitness parameters
Upper body pulling strength evaluation focusing on movement pattern quality and force production capacity
Progressive single leg movement evaluation from controlled step-downs to reactive single leg jumps across sagittal plane movements
Continuous monitoring of heart rate variability patterns to assess autonomic nervous system function and recovery status
Objective sleep tracking including sleep duration, efficiency, and architecture patterns using wearable technology

interventions.intervention_description: Comprehensive strength training program tailored to individual movement competencies and readiness levels, incorporating exercises that match the athlete's body and capabilities. Includes both free weights and machines based on available equipment and individual needs.

Progressive plyometric training using repeat hopping tests and counter movement jumps to improve reactive strength and power output. Includes both bilateral and unilateral exercises based on movement competency assessment.

Targeted interventions to address movement limitations and compensations identified through movement assessment. Includes mobility work, stability exercises, and movement re-education from basic positions to more complex patterns.
Low-intensity aerobic training performed at zone two heart rate to improve cardiovascular fitness and recovery capacity. Prescribed based on individual maximum heart rate and training zones.
High-intensity interval training protocols designed to improve anaerobic capacity and power output. Includes specific work-to-rest ratios based on individual testing results and sport demands.
Comprehensive sleep hygiene and optimization strategies to improve sleep quality and recovery. Includes monitoring and behavioral interventions to enhance sleep patterns.

Progressive single leg training program moving from slow controlled movements to fast reactive tasks. Includes step-downs, split squats, single leg jumps, and sport-specific lateral movements based on individual competency level.

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Movement competency is a prerequisite for power testing - if movement patterns are compromised, power assessments may not be valid or safe
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Matt states 'if you're not ready for it, I'm not testing it' and emphasizes assessing movement competency before progressing to power tests

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Poor movement competency often manifests as asymmetrical loading patterns between limbs
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Matt looks for 'waiting one side more than the other' during movement assessments and uses force displacement loops to identify asymmetries

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Power output is considered a crucial predictor of functionality across the lifespan
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Matt states power is 'one of the more important mechanical biomarkers that's gonna mark your longevity across the lifespan'

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Sleep quality and HRV are monitored together as indicators of recovery status
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Matt mentions monitoring 'resting heart rate, HRV sleep' as part of routine recovery assessment

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Body composition affects power output interpretation, with fat-free mass normalization providing more meaningful comparisons
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Matt emphasizes 'fat free mass normalize it' for power measures as 'much more informative value to compare between people'

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Plyometric function and anaerobic capacity both relate to high-intensity, explosive performance capabilities
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Matt uses repeat hop tests for plyometric function and 82-second repeated squat jump test for anaerobic capacity assessment

moderating_factors.description: Different sports require different movement competencies and testing approaches

recommendations.description: Critical technology and metrics categories are completely missing from extraction despite extensive discussion of force plates, wearable devices, and specific biomechanical metrics
Several specific assessments mentioned (82s repeated jump test, anaerobic speed reserve, incremental cycle test) were not captured in the extraction
Important constructs like 'plyometric function' and 'movement competency' need to be added to provide complete domain coverage
The extraction lacks the hierarchical relationships and decision trees that Matt describes (e.g., pain vs no-pain pathways, movement competency levels)
Matt's innovative machine learning approach to holistic assessment interpretation should be captured as a distinct intervention/methodology
The bifurcation logic and conditional assessment pathways described by Matt are crucial for practical application but missing from extraction

practitioner_domains.specialization_notes: Primary expertise area using both conventional western medicine and lifestyle medicine approaches

practitioner_domains.specialization_notes: Often overlaps with metabolic syndrome assessment

practitioner_domains.specialization_notes: Hospital and outpatient settings experience

practitioner_domains.domain_description: Six pillars approach: nutrition, physical activity, sleep, stress management, substance use reduction, and positive social connection for optimal health and functioning
practitioner_domains.specialization_notes: Foundation for preventing disease, treating existing conditions, and optimizing health span and lifespan

assessments.assessment_description: Blood test that measures average blood glucose levels over the past 3 months by examining glycated red blood cells. Does not require fasting and can be collected any time of day.
Blood test that measures blood glucose levels after an overnight fast to assess glucose metabolism and insulin resistance.
Blood test that measures insulin levels after an overnight fast, used in conjunction with fasting glucose to calculate HOMA-IR for insulin resistance assessment.
3-hour blood test that measures glucose and insulin response to a 75-gram glucose load. Requires fasting baseline measurements, glucose drink consumption, and follow-up blood draws at 2 hours.
Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry imaging study that provides detailed body composition analysis including body fat percentage, lean mass, and visceral adipose tissue measurements.
Physical measurements including height, weight, waist circumference, and waist-to-hip ratio to assess body composition and metabolic risk factors.

Structured interview to assess patient's weight trajectory, previous weight loss/gain attempts, eating disorder screening, medications affecting weight, and relationship with food and weight management.
Comprehensive questionnaire and interview covering nutrition, physical activity, sleep, stress management, substance use, and social connections to evaluate lifestyle factors impacting health.
Structured interview where patients provide detailed account of all foods and beverages consumed in the previous 24 hours, including portion sizes, preparation methods, and eating patterns.
Validated screening tool that assesses risk factors for obstructive sleep apnea including snoring, tiredness, observed apnea, blood pressure, BMI, age, neck circumference, and gender.
Broad screening tool designed for primary care settings to identify various sleep disorders including sleep apnea, insomnia, restless leg syndrome, and circadian rhythm disorders.

Validated questionnaire that assesses physical activity levels across different intensity categories (light, moderate, vigorous) and strength training frequency to compare against physical activity guidelines.
Brief validated instrument that measures subjective stress levels by assessing how unpredictable, uncontrollable, and overloaded individuals find their lives over the past month.
Wearable patch device worn for 2 weeks that continuously measures glucose levels in interstitial fluid, providing real-time glucose data and trends in response to meals, exercise, and sleep.

Comprehensive overnight monitoring of sleep patterns, breathing, heart rate, and other physiological parameters to diagnose sleep disorders such as sleep apnea, conducted in a sleep laboratory or at home.

interventions.intervention_description: Comprehensive lifestyle intervention targeting nutrition, physical activity, sleep, stress management, substance use reduction, and positive social connection to prevent disease and treat existing conditions like hypertension, diabetes, and obesity

Evidence-based protocol combining conventional western medicine (medications, procedures, surgeries as needed) with lifestyle interventions to manage the spectrum of insulin resistance from normal glycemic control to end-stage type 2 diabetes

Detailed nutritional assessment and intervention including 24-hour dietary recalls, food swaps, eating pattern modification, and use of food logging tools like apps, CGM data, and AI-powered meal tracking
Comprehensive sleep evaluation using validated questionnaires (GSAQ, Stop Bang, ISI) with referral to sleep studies when indicated, targeting sleep apnea, insomnia, and circadian rhythm disorders

Structured exercise program targeting 150 minutes moderate intensity or 75 minutes vigorous intensity weekly plus 2 days strength training, with wearable monitoring for accurate intensity categorization

interventions.intervention_name: Stress Management and Mental Health Support
interventions.intervention_description: Comprehensive stress assessment using PSS4 and mental health screening (GAD-7, PHQ-9) with interventions focused on balancing demands versus resources and developing effective coping strategies

Individualized weight management approach considering weight history, eating disorders screening, medical conditions, and medications, with focus on sustainable lifestyle changes rather than just weight loss

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Body composition, particularly visceral fat and BMI, correlates with insulin resistance and glucose management

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Weight management history provides context for interpreting current body composition measurements

construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Mental health assessment is the first priority when discussing stress to ensure stress isn't actually anxiety or other mood disorders

constraints_preferences.description: Limited vs moderate vs unlimited resources affecting assessment depth

recommendations.description: Add the 9 high-confidence assessment tools that were clearly described but missed in initial extraction (HOMA-IR, Stop-Bang, GSAQ, Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index, ISI, GAD-7, PHQ-9, IPAQ, Diet ID)
Include MD Calc app and Stilo CGM as specific technologies mentioned with detailed usage descriptions
Add Mental Health Assessment as a distinct construct separate from stress management, as it was clearly differentiated in the interview
Add specific scoring metrics for validated questionnaires (HOMA-IR score, Stop-Bang risk score, etc.) that have defined reference ranges
Include screening assessments for eating disorders and medication-induced weight changes as these were emphasized as critical first steps
Better capture the hierarchical relationships between screening tools (like GSAQ) and more specific assessments (like ISI) that follow positive screens
Conduct follow-up interview to capture the intervention side that was mentioned but not covered due to time constraints

assessments.assessment_description: A detailed interview process where patients describe everything they eat and drink from when they wake up in the morning until when they go to sleep at night, including timing, portions, and preparation methods

A digital tool where patients select their general dietary pattern (keto, vegan, etc.) and cultural preferences, then click on food pictures that match their regular eating patterns to generate a comprehensive dietary profile

A comprehensive interview covering all aspects of a patient's sleep routine from wake time to bedtime, including napping habits, stimulant use, screen exposure, caffeine timing, and nighttime behaviors
A standardized sleep tracking log used as part of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia protocols to monitor sleep patterns, duration, and quality over time
International Physical Activity Questionnaire modified with additional questions about resistance training to assess minutes of moderate to vigorous physical activity and strength training frequency

A standardized measurement tool to quantify the number of minutes of moderate to vigorous physical activity per week and number of days of strength training, designed to be collected as a vital sign during clinical visits

American College of Sports Medicine screening tool to assess risk factors and contraindications before starting an exercise program, particularly focusing on cardiovascular, metabolic, and musculoskeletal considerations
Clinical interview to identify chronic stress levels and their potential impact on metabolic health, including assessment of stress-related behaviors and coping mechanisms

interventions.intervention_description: Detailed interview about sleep habits from wake to sleep, followed by personalized high-value interventions based on CBTI principles. Includes setting early wake times, reducing blue light exposure from screens, managing caffeine timing, bed restriction techniques, and sleep logs. Requires ruling out and treating organic sleep disorders first.

Red-yellow-green light food categorization system where green light foods (whole plant foods, fatty fish) comprise 75% of meals, yellow light foods (low-fat dairy, poultry, eggs) are moderated to 25% or less, and red light foods (refined grains, processed meats, high-fat dairy) are minimized. Focuses on maximizing fiber intake and reducing calorie density for weight loss and insulin sensitivity improvement.

Target of 150+ minutes of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity per week plus strength training for all major muscle groups at least 2 days per week. Includes balance training for adults over 65. Uses ACSM pre-participation screening, heart rate monitoring, and step tracking (7-8,000 steps/day). Emphasizes patient preference and motivational interviewing approaches.
Implementation of MBSR techniques and mindfulness-based practices to reduce chronic stress levels. Often combined with exercise as dual-purpose stress reduction and physical activity intervention.

Evidence-based medication protocols following ADA guidelines, with metformin as first-line for pre-diabetes and type 2 diabetes. GLP-1 agonists preferred for patients with comorbid obesity, cardiovascular risk factors. Medication intensity based on A1C levels at diagnosis. Shared decision-making approach with option to reduce medications as lifestyle improvements occur.

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Chronic sleep deprivation (6 or less hours) increases risk of insulin resistance and cardiometabolic conditions
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Studies show sleep hygiene interventions can be effective in increasing sleep duration and reducing cardiometabolic risk

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Poor sleep quality contributes to insulin resistance development
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Sleep disorders and poor sleep hygiene are linked to cardiometabolic conditions

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Elevated visceral adipose tissue and waist circumference predispose to insulin resistance by causing fat accumulation in liver and skeletal muscle
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Fat in tissues that should not have fat (liver, skeletal muscle) causes dysfunction and poor insulin response

construct_relationships.relationship_description: High saturated fat and refined grain intake increases insulin resistance; whole plant foods improve insulin sensitivity
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Low calorie density foods allow weight loss and fat removal from tissues; diabetes can be put into remission with dietary changes

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Moderate to vigorous physical activity and resistance training improve insulin sensitivity
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Diabetes Prevention Program showed this level of activity can reverse pre-diabetes alongside nutrition intervention

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Optimizing lean muscle mass through strength training improves insulin sensitivity
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Strength training all major muscle groups is part of effective insulin resistance intervention

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Chronic stress levels are linked to insulin resistance development
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Established but less well-established link between chronic stress and insulin resistance

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Low calorie density foods enable weight loss and fat removal from problematic tissues
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Green light foods have fewer calories per pound, enabling sustainable weight management

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Strength training increases lean muscle mass
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Resistance training all major muscle groups optimizes lean muscle mass

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Whole plant foods improve cardiovascular health while high animal protein and saturated fat worsen it
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Low carb diets can increase cholesterol and blood pressure; plant foods reduce cardiovascular disease risk

interpretation_factors: General food patterns rather than specific daily intake
Minutes of moderate to vigorous activity per week

intervention_construct_links.timeline_expectations: Follow-up every 4-6 weeks; longer timeline for routine establishment

potential_missed_entities.evidence_in_transcript: the concept of calorie density is key for addressing insulin resistance because the goal is weight loss and eating high amounts of whole plant foods allow people to feel satiated
we have fat and tissues that should not have fat. So that is primarily the liver and skeletal muscle... these tissues start to accumulate fat
I like the ACSM pre-articipation exercise screening tool. I think that's a really nice tool to understand if people are at risk for complications
there's actually an initiative called the physical activity vital sign... to quantify the number of minutes of moderate to vigorous physical activity per week

the best treatment for insomnia is actually largely lifestyle driven with using a protocol called cognitive behavior, cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia... it is called CBTI and it is a standardized intervention
another one that has a lot of evidence for it is mindfulness-based stress reduction MBSR. So mindfulness based practices are also kind of a cornerstone of interventions

I really like the red yellow green light framework. Yellow red I'm sorry green light meaning eat these foods add lib... yellow light foods, meaning let's really moderate portions... red light being things that we really want to avoid
sleep hygiene interventions can be effective in increasing the duration of sleep... decreasing blue light exposure primarily through phone, tablet, computer screens... bed restriction
the first line medication for type 2 diabetes is metformin... the GLP1s I think are one of my favorite because of the often comorbid overweight obesity, hypertension
this is where CGMs could are really fantastic and can really shine because they can alert people to hypoglycemia and we can query it to see what's going on
I would love for us to track people's heart rate and see what zone they're getting into... so we can very accurately capture if they're light, moderate, vigorous physical activity
that can also involve like a sleep log that is part of the traditional CBTI program
I personally like the talk test. I think that that's just a very accessible way for people to understand their level of exertion and intensity
there's a lot more data coming out now showing that like 7 to 8,000 steps per day does improve you know a lot of cardium metabolic health outcomes
I want most adults to be sleeping 7 to n hours on average every night. older adults require a little bit less sleep... looking at more like 7 to eight hours per night
we do want them to have higher protein intake... we want them to get at least 1.2 grams per kilogram of body weight of protein per day

I think everybody who works with patients can benefit from motivational interviewing... using those motivational interviewing techniques, to get them a program that the patient really wants to and enjoys doing

recommendations.description: Add standardized intervention protocols like CBTI and MBSR as distinct intervention entities with their specific components and delivery methods
Include calorie density and ectopic fat accumulation as key pathophysiological constructs that inform intervention selection
Add specialized assessment tools like ACSM screening and Physical Activity Vital Sign that have specific protocols and risk stratification capabilities
Include monitoring technologies (CGMs, wearables, sleep logs) as distinct entities with specific use cases and integration points
Add specific quantitative thresholds and targets (sleep duration, protein intake, steps, exercise intensity measures) as measurable metrics
Better capture the temporal relationships and follow-up schedules (2-4 weeks for most interventions, 4-6 weeks for physical activity)
Document the Red-Yellow-Green Light food framework as a structured intervention approach with specific food categorizations
Include motivational interviewing and behavior change strategies as foundational constructs that moderate intervention effectiveness

practitioner_domains.domain_description: Assessment and management of liver function, metabolic dysfunction associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD), and liver-related conditions including fibrosis staging and comprehensive liver health evaluation
practitioner_domains.specialization_notes: Focus on metabolic dysfunction associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD), formerly known as NAFLD/NASH, which is now the most common cause of cirrhosis. Includes screening, staging, and lifestyle intervention protocols.

practitioner_domains.domain_description: Management of insulin resistance, metabolic syndrome, obesity, and related cardiometabolic conditions that contribute to liver dysfunction
practitioner_domains.specialization_notes: Integrated approach addressing metabolic risk factors including insulin resistance, obesity, hypertension, and dyslipidemia as they relate to liver health outcomes.

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Assessment of liver enzymes (AST, ALT) with optimal ranges of 20s for women and 30s for men, evaluated through comprehensive metabolic panel
constructs_mentioned.assessment_context: Routine screening through CMP, non-fasted blood draw, controlling for alcohol intake and strenuous exercise

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Quantification of liver scarring using FIB-4 index and elastography (fibroscan) with stages F0-F4, where F0 indicates fat deposits without fibrosis and F4 represents advanced cirrhosis
constructs_mentioned.assessment_context: FIB-4 index using liver enzymes, platelets, and age; elastography for definitive staging; age-specific thresholds (<65: 1.3 cutoff, >65: 2.0 cutoff)

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Assessment of visceral adipose tissue through BMI, waist circumference, waist-to-hip ratio, DEXA, or MRI to evaluate metabolic risk factors
constructs_mentioned.assessment_context: Initial intake assessment for MASLD risk stratification, focusing on visceral adiposity measurements

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Metabolic dysfunction contributing to hepatic fat deposition and liver disease progression
constructs_mentioned.assessment_context: Medical history assessment and blood panel evaluation as part of metabolic risk factor identification

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Hypertension management as both a risk factor for MASLD and comorbid condition requiring treatment
constructs_mentioned.assessment_context: Vital signs assessment during initial intake and ongoing monitoring as part of cardiometabolic risk management

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Mediterranean or plant-forward dietary patterns emphasizing fruits, vegetables, whole grains, legumes, with avoidance of fructose and limitation of saturated fats
constructs_mentioned.assessment_context: Lifestyle intervention targeting 5-10% weight loss depending on fibrosis stage, with specific focus on hepatoprotective dietary patterns

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Aerobic and resistance training following physical activity guidelines (150 min/week moderate-vigorous activity, 2 days/week resistance training)
constructs_mentioned.assessment_context: Combined with nutrition intervention for optimal liver fat reduction and insulin sensitivity improvement

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Quantification and management of alcohol intake frequency and quantity as it relates to liver health and disease progression
constructs_mentioned.assessment_context: Lifestyle parameter assessment with education on avoiding high-risk alcohol use and binge drinking patterns

assessments.assessment_description: Blood test that includes liver function tests (AST and ALT enzymes) to evaluate liver health and identify dysfunction. Does not require fasting.
Algorithm using liver enzymes, platelets, and age to assess risk of advanced fibrosis in patients with metabolic risk factors. High negative predictive value for ruling out advanced fibrosis.

assessments.assessment_name: Body Mass Index and Anthropometric Measurements
assessments.assessment_description: Assessment of BMI, waist circumference, waist-to-hip ratio, and waist-to-height ratio to indirectly assess visceral adipose tissue risk.
Advanced imaging method to quantify visceral adipose tissue and provide detailed body composition analysis.
Imaging to assess liver contour and identify fat deposits in the liver. Cannot determine degree of fibrosis but commonly performed for initial evaluation.
Specialized ultrasound that measures liver stiffness to determine presence and stage of fibrosis (F0-F4 staging). Essential for determining management approach.
Blood test to measure platelet count, which is used as part of the FIB-4 index calculation. Does not require fasting.
Assessment of blood pressure as hypertension is a risk factor for metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease.
Blood test including Hepatitis B surface antigen and Hepatitis C antibody to rule out viral hepatitis as cause of liver dysfunction.
Systematic assessment of alcohol intake frequency and quantity to evaluate contribution to liver dysfunction and guide intervention.
Evaluation of dietary patterns, particularly focusing on saturated fat intake, fructose consumption, and adherence to plant-forward dietary patterns.

Evaluation of current aerobic and resistance training activities to determine compliance with physical activity guidelines (150 minutes moderate-vigorous activity per week, resistance training 2 days per week).

interventions.intervention_description: Plant-forward dietary pattern emphasizing fruits, vegetables, whole grains, beans, peas, lentils, nuts, seeds, fatty fish, and low-fat dairy while avoiding high saturated fat foods and fructose

interventions.intervention_name: Combined Aerobic and Resistance Training Program
interventions.intervention_description: 150 minutes per week of moderate to vigorous aerobic activity plus resistance training two days per week, following Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans
Targeted weight loss of 5% body weight for fat reduction, 7% for steatohepatitis reversal, and 10% for fibrosis improvement through combined nutrition and exercise interventions
High-touch support program with 1-2 sessions per week for 12+ weeks, gradually spacing to monthly/quarterly follow-ups, involving registered dietitians and exercise specialists
Counseling and support to avoid high-risk alcohol consumption, binge drinking, and ideally minimize or eliminate alcohol intake to prevent liver damage progression
Education and counseling to avoid fructose-containing beverages including juices, sodas, energy drinks, and sweetened teas that contribute to liver fat accumulation
Recommendation for two cups of coffee daily, which has been shown to reduce risk of liver fibrosis

Comprehensive review and elimination of hepatotoxic supplements including anabolic steroids, green tea extract, multi-ingredient nutritional supplements, high-dose turmeric/curcumin, black cohosh, and red yeast rice
Comprehensive treatment of metabolic risk factors including insulin resistance, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and cardiovascular disease through integrated care approach
Prescription of GLP-1 medications in conjunction with intensive lifestyle intervention for patients with obesity and metabolic dysfunction to improve weight loss and insulin sensitivity
Individualized intervention approach based on patient's stage of change (pre-contemplation, contemplation, preparation, action, maintenance) using transtheoretical model principles
Referral to hepatologist for patients with F2 or higher fibrosis for advanced monitoring, cancer screening, portal hypertension assessment, and access to specialized medications like pioglitazone

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Insulin resistance contributes to the pathophysiology of fat being deposited into the liver
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: When we increase insulin sensitivity we are able to better process blood sugar and reduce the contribution of stores going into the liver itself

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Visceral adipose tissue and excess body weight contribute to metabolic dysfunction associated steatotic liver disease
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Weight loss pulls fat out of the liver - as low as 5% body weight loss shows improvement in fat deposits

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Physical activity improves insulin sensitivity
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Nutrition and physical activity can improve insulin resistance

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Dietary patterns, particularly saturated fat and fructose consumption, directly affect liver health
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Excess saturated fat needs to be deposited somewhere and finds its way to the liver; fructose consumption contributes to development and worsening of liver disease

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Alcohol consumption directly affects liver enzymes and contributes to liver dysfunction
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Alcohol affects the liver significantly; avoiding high-risk alcohol consumption is key for liver health

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Fibrosis staging represents the progression of liver dysfunction from fat deposits to scarring
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Spectrum from F0 (fat deposits, no scarring) to F4 (advanced fibrosis/cirrhosis)

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Hypertension is a metabolic risk factor that clusters with liver dysfunction
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Hypertension can clue us into who may be at risk for metabolic dysfunction associated steatotic liver disease

client_goals.goal_description: Early detection and reversal of metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD)
client_goals.timeline: Lifelong intervention with intensive phase of 12+ weeks

client_goals.goal_description: Optimize cardiometabolic health and manage comorbidities
Prevent progression to advanced fibrosis and cirrhosis

constraints_preferences.description: Need for specialized imaging (elastography/fibroscan) and hepatology referral
constraints_preferences.impact_on_assessment: May require referral to facilities with advanced imaging capabilities
constraints_preferences.impact_on_intervention: Advanced fibrosis stages (F2+) require specialist management
workaround_strategies: Use FIB-4 index as initial screening

constraints_preferences.description: Presence of multiple comorbidities (diabetes, hypertension, cardiovascular disease)
constraints_preferences.impact_on_assessment: Requires comprehensive metabolic panel and multiple system evaluation
constraints_preferences.impact_on_intervention: Need for coordinated care addressing all metabolic conditions simultaneously

constraints_preferences.description: Patient readiness for lifestyle change varies (stages of change model)
constraints_preferences.impact_on_assessment: Need to assess motivation and readiness for change
constraints_preferences.impact_on_intervention: Requires stage-matched interventions based on patient's readiness

moderating_factors.description: Adults over 65 have different FIB-4 thresholds and may have different response rates
moderating_factors.what_it_affects: FIB-4 interpretation and prognosis for intervention success
moderating_factors.management_approach: Use age-adjusted FIB-4 cutoffs (>2.0 for 65+) and adjust expectations for intervention outcomes

moderating_factors.description: Higher fibrosis stages (F3-F4) have lower likelihood of reversal
moderating_factors.what_it_affects: Intervention effectiveness and prognosis
moderating_factors.management_approach: Adjust weight loss targets (10% for fibrosis reversal) and focus on preventing progression rather than reversal

moderating_factors.description: Recent alcohol intake can elevate liver enzymes and affect assessment accuracy
moderating_factors.what_it_affects: Liver function test results and diagnostic accuracy
moderating_factors.management_approach: Repeat testing after period of abstinence, provide alcohol counseling, monitor consumption patterns

moderating_factors.description: Certain supplements and medications can cause liver injury or affect test results
moderating_factors.what_it_affects: Assessment accuracy and liver health outcomes
moderating_factors.management_approach: Comprehensive medication/supplement review, discontinue hepatotoxic supplements, use LiverTox database for screening

individual_differences.description: Different optimal liver enzyme ranges for men and women
individual_differences.assessment_implications: ALT targets: 20s for women, 30s for men; AST similar ranges
individual_differences.intervention_implications: May need sex-specific targets for monitoring intervention success

individual_differences.description: Presence of insulin resistance, obesity, hypertension affects screening approach
individual_differences.assessment_implications: FIB-4 screening recommended only for those with metabolic risk factors to avoid overdiagnosis
individual_differences.intervention_implications: Requires comprehensive metabolic intervention addressing all risk factors simultaneously

individual_differences.description: Visceral adiposity particularly relevant for MASLD risk and intervention targeting
individual_differences.assessment_implications: Need for body composition assessment beyond BMI (DEXA, MRI, waist measurements)
individual_differences.intervention_implications: Focus on interventions that specifically target visceral fat reduction

individual_differences.difference_factor: Training status and physical activity level
individual_differences.description: Current fitness level affects intervention design and progression
individual_differences.assessment_implications: Avoid testing immediately after strenuous exercise
individual_differences.intervention_implications: Individualized progression for aerobic and resistance training based on current capacity

constructs_mentioned.assessment_context: Primary focus construct - assessed via Prime Diet Quality Score Screener, Mini-EAT questionnaire, and comprehensive 24-hour dietary recalls

constructs_mentioned.assessment_context: Critical for athletic performance and health outcomes, assessed through dietary recalls and compared to sport-specific energy demands

constructs_mentioned.assessment_context: Used as objective data before consultations, particularly important for athletes and older populations

constructs_mentioned.assessment_context: Assessed for adequacy, timing throughout day, and appropriateness for sport and body type

constructs_mentioned.assessment_context: Evaluated for training periodization, game day nutrition, and travel scenarios

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Adequacy of vitamins and minerals, particularly important for those with dietary restrictions
constructs_mentioned.assessment_context: Assessed through blood work and dietary analysis, especially for vegan athletes and those with restrictions

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Individual capability in food procurement, preparation, and safety practices

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Digestive comfort and function, particularly around training and competition

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Psychological and behavioral patterns around eating that influence nutritional behaviors
constructs_mentioned.assessment_context: Critical assessment that may require mental health referral, particularly important for female athletes and weight-class sports

assessments.assessment_description: A 13-question validated screening tool that evaluates dietary quality by assessing frequency and portions of key food groups including processed meats, red meats, fish, dairy, fast food, sodas, grains, sweets, legumes, vegetables, whole fruits, and nuts/seeds. Provides a scoring system to compare nutrient density against general health recommendations.

A 9-question validated screening tool for dietary quality assessment that includes questions about alcohol consumption and asks about processed versus unprocessed foods. Similar to PDQS but with slightly different question formatting and additional alcohol assessment.

Comprehensive one-on-one interview process where practitioner conducts detailed interrogation of complete daily food intake including specific foods, brands, portions, cooking methods, timing, and eating patterns. Includes assessment across different scenarios (game days, travel days, home vs facility eating) and evaluation of food groups, nutrient density, and eating behaviors.

Visual documentation of actual food intake through photographs to validate and compare against dietary recall information. Used to improve accuracy of portion size estimation and identify discrepancies between reported and actual intake.

interventions.intervention_description: Targeting 4-5 cups of combined fruits and vegetables per day to decrease disease risk over time. Starting with preferred fruits/vegetables and gradually building variety.

interventions.intervention_name: Food Group Completion Assessment and Addition
interventions.intervention_description: Identifying missing food groups in the diet and incorporating them through enjoyable, convenient options that fit the individual's preferences and schedule.
Introducing whole grains like whole wheat bread or pasta to replace some refined grains when appropriate, considering overall fiber intake from other plant-based foods.
Ensuring adequate spacing of macronutrients throughout the day, particularly carbohydrates around training times, with consistent frequency and appropriate portions.

Creating detailed meal plans with multiple options for each meal period, incorporating existing preferred foods and habits while addressing nutritional gaps. Plans consider cooking ability, food access, and schedule constraints.
Using visual plate ratios with different food groups for individuals who prefer less detailed approaches, adapted for different types of days or goals.

construct_relationships.relationship_description: High dietary quality alone is insufficient if energy intake is inadequate - overall energy needs must be met even if it requires including lower nutrient density foods
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Cricket athlete example - decent dietary quality but not getting enough overall energy; athletic populations needing candy for energy intake

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Inadequate energy intake leads to inability to maintain body weight or muscle mass throughout seasons
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Vegan athlete example - history of not keeping on body weight or muscle mass due to energy intake issues

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Adequate protein and carbohydrate intake is necessary to maintain body composition, especially during training seasons
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Vegan athlete needing adequate protein and carbohydrate to maintain body composition

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Poor relationship with food dictates eating behaviors and habits, overriding nutrition knowledge and preventing dietary quality improvements
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Practitioner observation that relationship with food 'is truly not even knowledge about nutrition... It's really mindset'

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Timing of food intake around training and competition affects GI comfort and function
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Assessment of GI issues around training/competition and 'game stomach' with nerves affecting eating ability

potential_missed_entities.evidence_in_transcript: in a situation where you are unable to really do that full recall with someone, there are food frequency questionnaires and things like that available
there's also the healthy eating index which compares to the dietary guidelines for Americans
whenever possible, having some sort of picture food log to compare can be extremely useful
food safety. Honestly, like I there you I have some athletes who will not eat chicken at home because they are afraid of the food safety aspect of it
cooking like um self-efficacy with actually getting food on the table for themselves, whether that be grocery shopping, maintaining a kitchen with food, actually preparing the food
if we have just any situation we're talking about food access and availability... do they have financial resources available to to be taking care of that
Travel is really big of course like what their schedule looks like and what's possible for them
the big view here is are we hitting all the food groups period. Are you are you missing any food groups?
in person you are always going to get a little bit more information... if I say they say okay I always have rice for dinner i'm like okay well how much do you have
so I try to get brands whenever I can for not only better nutrition information but also just preferences and habits
Are we getting enough of those? So if we look at like... starches within the carbohydrate umbrella. Are we getting those throughout the day?
there is some research that shows that having like four to five cups of combined fruits and veggies a day can be really helpful
There are some tools that like you can pay for where you people do this whole like survey thing they fill out where there's like pictures

recommendations.description: Add Food Frequency Questionnaire, Healthy Eating Index, and Picture Food Log as formal assessment methods with detailed specifications
Include Cooking Self-Efficacy and Food Access/Availability as distinct constructs with their own assessment and intervention pathways
Develop more granular intervention categories for food group completion, portion education, and brand-specific recommendations
Establish specific metrics for food group frequency and standardized serving recommendations (e.g., 4-5 cups fruits/vegetables)
Better define relationships between constructs (e.g., how food access influences dietary quality assessment choice)
Include athlete state considerations (injury, mood, travel) as contextual factors that influence assessment timing and interpretation

Include additional sleep metrics like Sleep Latency, Movement/Awake Time, and Sleep Regularity Index
Create subcategories for behavioral interventions (environment, timing, lifestyle) vs. technological interventions
Better define relationships between sleep and other constructs (physical activity, nutrition, cognitive performance, illness)
Expand technology categories to include non-wearable devices (mattress toppers, nearables)
Add contextual modifiers for different populations (new parents, shift workers, athletes vs. general population)
Include validation criteria and reference ranges for each assessment method
Define clear protocols for combining multiple assessment methods and interpreting conflicting data

assessments.assessment_description: Complete Blood Count with differential - a comprehensive blood test that evaluates red blood cells, white blood cells, and their various components to assess immune function, infection status, and overall blood health
Serum test measuring vitamin B12 levels to assess DNA synthesis capability, cellular turnover, and mitochondrial ATP synthesis function
Serum test measuring 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels to assess vitamin D status for immune function and bone health
Blood test measuring the average size of red blood cells to assess DNA synthesis and identify potential B12/folate deficiencies or iron deficiency

interventions.intervention_name: Reishi Mushroom Supplementation for Low Neutrophils
interventions.intervention_description: Reishi mushroom supplementation to work at the bone marrow level to increase neutrophil count when neutrophils are low and monocytes are not elevated. Specific products mentioned include MRS formula by Pure Encapsulations or NSF certified reishi mushroom (bioel sport mushroom).
Use of echinacea and grapefruit seed extract when monocytes are elevated, indicating potential viral infection or chronic inflammation.

Use of berberine or wormwood for elevated eosinophils indicating parasitic infection. May include antibiotics like metronidazole depending on stool sample results showing parasites like blastocystis hominis or giardia.

For elevated basophils indicating allergies: Designs for Health Biofizz (vitamin C and bioflavonoids) one scoop daily, plus quercetin and nettles combination product two capsules three times daily until allergen identification/removal or season change. Also includes sublingual immunotherapy from Quantum Allergy for environmental allergens.
Addressing dehydration when red blood cell count, hemoglobin, and hematocrit are all elevated, indicating concentrated blood due to fluid loss.

For B12 levels below 600 (optimal): 1000 mcg sublingual B12 daily, or 5000 mcg B12 intramuscular injection weekly for 4 weeks followed by one week washout before retesting. Sublingual preferred for absorption, injections for compliance issues or pernicious anemia.

For low vitamin D (Sean at 30, wanting 60+ for immune protection): 10,000 IU daily for one month without vitamin K for rapid increase, then maintenance dose of 4000 IU with vitamin K (100-200 mcg K2). Retest after 3 months. Higher doses needed for northern hemisphere and darker skin pigmentation.
Reishi mushroom supplementation for several weeks before PRP procedures to increase platelet count in patients with low-normal platelets.

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Neutrophil count is a component that contributes to the total white blood cell count
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: White blood cell count is comprised of adding up the differential, including neutrophils

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Neutrophil count is the numerator in calculating the neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: We want to see a neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio of 2:1, with neutrophils being twice as robust as lymphocytes

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Dehydration causes elevated hemoglobin levels due to blood concentration
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: When red blood cell count is high, I think about dehydration and look for high hemoglobin and high hematocrit

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Low vitamin B12 causes enlarged red blood cells (high MCV) due to impaired DNA synthesis
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Mean corpuscular volume greater than 90 leads us to test for vitamin B12 and B9, as DNA synthesis becomes sluggish

construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Physical exam includes blood pressure testing and looking at heart rate variability from devices like Whoop and Oura
